where should i include this"<!-- Include the EmailJS SDK from CDN --> <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@emailjs/browser@3/dist/email.min.js"></script>"

You should include the EmailJS SDK CDN script in your HTML file, typically just before the closing </body> tag or in the <head> section. Placing it before the closing </body> tag is generally recommended for better page load performance.

Here’s how and where to include it:

Option 1: Before the Closing </body> Tag (Recommended)

Place the script tag just before the closing </body> tag. This ensures that the HTML content loads first, and the script doesn’t block the rendering of the page.

Example:

html
Copy
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Contact Form</title>
</head>
<body>
    <form id="contactForm">
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="name">Your Name</label>
            <input type="text" id="name" name="name" placeholder="Enter your name" required>
        </div>
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="contact-info">Phone or Email</label>
            <input type="text" id="contact-info" name="contact-info" placeholder="Enter your phone or email" required>
        </div>
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="message">Message</label>
            <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Enter your message" required></textarea>
        </div>
        <button type="submit">Send Message</button>
    </form>
    <div id="form-message"></div>

    <!-- Include the EmailJS SDK from CDN -->
    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@emailjs/browser@3/dist/email.min.js"></script>
    <!-- Include your local script.js -->
    <script src="js/script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>
Run HTML

Option 2: In the <head> Section

You can also include the script in the <head> section, but this might block the rendering of the page until the script is loaded. To avoid this, you can use the defer attribute.

Example:

html
Copy
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Contact Form</title>
    <!-- Include the EmailJS SDK from CDN -->
    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@emailjs/browser@3/dist/email.min.js" defer></script>
    <!-- Include your local script.js -->
    <script src="js/script.js" defer></script>
</head>
<body>
    <form id="contactForm">
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="name">Your Name</label>
            <input type="text" id="name" name="name" placeholder="Enter your name" required>
        </div>
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="contact-info">Phone or Email</label>
            <input type="text" id="contact-info" name="contact-info" placeholder="Enter your phone or email" required>
        </div>
        <div class="form-group">
            <label for="message">Message</label>
            <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Enter your message" required></textarea>
        </div>
        <button type="submit">Send Message</button>
    </form>
    <div id="form-message"></div>
</body>
</html>
Run HTML

Why Before </body> is Recommended

  • Faster Page Load: Scripts at the end of the body don’t block the rendering of the page, so users see the content faster.

  • DOM Readiness: By the time the script runs, the DOM (HTML structure) is fully loaded, so you don’t need to worry about elements not being available.

Key Points

  1. Order of Scripts:

    • Include the EmailJS SDK before your custom script (script.js) because your custom script depends on the EmailJS SDK.

  2. Defer Attribute:

    • If you include the script in the <head>, use the defer attribute to ensure the script runs after the DOM is fully loaded.

  3. Testing:

    • After including the script, test your form to ensure it works correctly.

Final Example

Here’s the complete setup with the EmailJS SDK included before the closing </body> tag:

write for mr updated script.js

Here’s the updated script.js file that integrates with EmailJS using your provided Service ID, Template ID, and Public Key. This script will handle the form submission and send the email using EmailJS.

Updated script.js

javascript
Copy
// Initialize EmailJS with your Public Key
emailjs.init('hfbWk-2-MUzwJKl4'); // Replace with your Public Key

// Add an event listener to the form
document.getElementById('contactForm').addEventListener('submit', function (e) {
    e.preventDefault(); // Prevent the default form submission

    // Get form data
    const name = document.getElementById('name').value;
    const contactInfo = document.getElementById('contact-info').value;
    const message = document.getElementById('message').value;

    // Send email using EmailJS
    emailjs.send('service_vqll2la', 'template_e8rlxer', {
        name: name,
        contact_info: contactInfo,
        message: message,
    })
    .then(() => {
        // Display success message
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Thank you! Your message has been sent.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'green';

        // Clear the form (optional)
        document.getElementById('contactForm').reset();
    }, (error) => {
        // Display error message
        console.error('Error:', error);
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
    });
});

Explanation of the Code

  1. Initialize EmailJS:

    • emailjs.init('hfbWk-2-MUzwJKl4'): Initializes EmailJS with your Public Key.

  2. Form Submission Handling:

    • The form’s submit event is intercepted using e.preventDefault() to prevent the default form submission behavior.

    • The form data (name, contact info, and message) is retrieved using document.getElementById().

  3. Send Email:

    • emailjs.send() is used to send the email. It takes the following parameters:

      • service_vqll2la: Your Service ID.

      • template_e8rlxer: Your Template ID.

      • { name, contact_info, message }: The dynamic data to be inserted into the email template.

  4. Success and Error Handling:

    • If the email is sent successfully, a success message is displayed, and the form is reset (optional).

    • If there’s an error, an error message is displayed, and the error is logged to the console.

How to Use

  1. Save the above code in a file named script.js inside your js folder.

  2. Ensure your index.html file includes the EmailJS SDK and your script.js file:

    html
    Copy
    <!-- Include the EmailJS SDK from CDN -->
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@emailjs/browser@3/dist/email.min.js"></script>
<!-- Include your local script.js -->
<script src="js/script.js"></script>
    Run HTML

  3. Test the form:

    • Fill out the form and click "Send Message."

    • Check your email inbox to verify that the message was sent successfully.

are the variables used in templete supposed to match with ones in html?

Yes, the variables used in the EmailJS template must match the keys you use in your JavaScript code when sending the email. These variables act as placeholders in your email template, and EmailJS replaces them with the actual data you provide.

How It Works

  1. Template Variables:

    • In the EmailJS dashboard, you define variables in your email template using double curly braces, e.g., {{name}}, {{contact_info}}, {{message}}.

  2. JavaScript Data:

    • When you call emailjs.send(), you pass an object containing the data. The keys in this object must match the variables in your template.

Example

EmailJS Template:

Copy
Subject: New Message from {{name}}

Name: {{name}}
Contact Info: {{contact_info}}
Message: {{message}}

JavaScript Code:

javascript
Copy
emailjs.send('service_vqll2la', 'template_e8rlxer', {
    name: 'John Doe', // This matches {{name}} in the template
    contact_info: 'john@example.com', // This matches {{contact_info}} in the template
    message: 'Hello, this is a test message.', // This matches {{message}} in the template
});

Key Points

  1. Variable Names Must Match:

    • The keys in the JavaScript object (name, contact_info, message) must exactly match the variable names in the EmailJS template ({{name}}, {{contact_info}}, {{message}}).

  2. Case-Sensitive:

    • Variable names are case-sensitive. For example, {{name}} is different from {{Name}}.

  3. Dynamic Data from Form:

    • In your case, the data is dynamically retrieved from the form fields, so the keys in the JavaScript object must match the template variables.

Updated script.js with Matching Variables

Here’s the updated script.js file with the correct variable names to match your template:

javascript
Copy
// Initialize EmailJS with your Public Key

    // Get form data
    const name = document.getElementById('name').value;
    const contactInfo = document.getElementById('contact-info').value;
    const message = document.getElementById('message').value;

    // Send email using EmailJS
    emailjs.send('service_vqll2la', 'template_e8rlxer', {
        name: name, // Matches {{name}} in the template
        contact_info: contactInfo, // Matches {{contact_info}} in the template
        message: message, // Matches {{message}} in the template
    })
    .then(() => {
        // Display success message
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Thank you! Your message has been sent.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'green';

        // Clear the form (optional)
        document.getElementById('contactForm').reset();
    }, (error) => {
        // Display error message
        console.error('Error:', error);
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
    });
});

why cant test?

The error message "400 Please create your first service" indicates that EmailJS cannot find the Service ID you’re trying to use. This usually happens when:

  1. The Service ID is missing or incorrect.

  2. The Service has not been created in your EmailJS account.

How to Fix It

Step 1: Verify the Service ID

  1. Go to the EmailJS Dashboard.

  2. Navigate to Email Services.

  3. Check if the service with ID service_vqll2la exists.

    • If it doesn’t exist, you need to create a new service.

    • If it exists, double-check the ID for typos.

Step 2: Create a New Service (If Needed)

  1. In the EmailJS dashboard, click on Email Services.

  2. Click Add New Service.

  3. Choose your email provider (e.g., Gmail).

  4. Follow the prompts to connect your email account.

  5. After creating the service, copy the Service ID.

Step 3: Update the JavaScript Code

Replace the empty "" in the emailjs.send() function with the correct Service ID. For example:

javascript
Copy
emailjs.send("service_vqll2la", "template_e8rlxer", {
    name: "aime_serge",
    contact_info: "220aime@gmail.com",
    message: "message njfjefcss",
});

Step 4: Test Again

  1. Go back to the Test Template section in the EmailJS dashboard.

  2. Fill in the form with test data.

  3. Click Send Test Email.

Common Issues and Fixes

  1. Service Not Found:

    • Ensure the Service ID is correct and matches the one in your EmailJS dashboard.

    • If the service doesn’t exist, create a new one.

  2. Template Not Found:

    • Ensure the Template ID (template_e8rlxer) is correct and matches the one in your EmailJS dashboard.

  3. Public Key Not Set:

    • Ensure you’ve initialized EmailJS with your Public Key:

      javascript
      Copy
      emailjs.init('hfbWk-2-MUzwJKl4'); // Replace with your Public Key

  4. Incorrect Variable Names:

    • Ensure the variable names in the template match the keys in the JavaScript object.

Example of Correct Setup

JavaScript Code:

javascript
Copy
// Initialize EmailJS with your Public Key
emailjs.init('hfbWk-2-MUzwJKl4'); // Replace with your Public Key

// Send email using EmailJS
emailjs.send('service_vqll2la', 'template_e8rlxer', {
    name: 'aime_serge',
    contact_info: '220aime@gmail.com',
    message: 'message njfjefcss',
})
.then(() => {
    console.log('Email sent successfully!');
}, (error) => {
    console.error('Error:', error);
});

To enforce validation for the name, email, and message fields in your form, you can use HTML5 validation and JavaScript. Here's how you can implement it:

1. Add Required Fields and Email Validation (HTML)

Use the required attribute to make the name and email fields mandatory. Use the type="email" attribute to enforce email validation.

html
Copy

    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="name">Your Name <span style="color: red;">*</span></label>
        <input type="text" id="name" name="name" placeholder="Enter your name" required>

    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="contact-info">Email <span style="color: red;">*</span></label>
        <input type="email" id="contact-info" name="contact-info" placeholder="Enter your email" required>
    </div>
    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="message">Message <span style="color: red;">*</span></label>
        <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Enter your message" required></textarea>
    </div>
    <button type="submit">Send Message</button>
</form>
<div id="form-message"></div>
Run HTML

  • The <span style="color: red;">*</span> adds a red asterisk (*) to indicate required fields.

  • The required attribute ensures the fields cannot be left empty.

  • The type="email" attribute ensures the email field accepts only valid email addresses.

2. Add Custom Validation for the Message (JavaScript)

Use JavaScript to enforce additional validation rules, such as ensuring the message contains more than one word.

Updated script.js:

javascript
Copy
// Initialize EmailJS with your Public Key
emailjs.init('hfbWk-2-MUzwJKl4'); // Replace with your Public Key

// Add an event listener to the form
document.getElementById('contactForm').addEventListener('submit', function (e) {
    e.preventDefault(); // Prevent the default form submission

    // Get form data
    const name = document.getElementById('name').value;
    const contactInfo = document.getElementById('contact-info').value;
    const message = document.getElementById('message').value;

    // Validate email format
    const emailPattern = /^[^\s@]+@[^\s@]+\.[^\s@]+$/;
    if (!emailPattern.test(contactInfo)) {
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Please enter a valid email address.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
        return; // Stop further execution
    }

    // Validate message length (more than one word)
    const messageWords = message.trim().split(/\s+/);
    if (messageWords.length < 2) {
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Please write more than one word for the message.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
        return; // Stop further execution
    }

    // Send email using EmailJS
    emailjs.send('service_vqll2la', 'template_e8rlxer', {
        name: name,
        contact_info: contactInfo,
        message: message,
    })
    .then(() => {
        // Display success message
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Thank you! Your message has been sent.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'green';

        // Clear the form (optional)
        document.getElementById('contactForm').reset();
    }, (error) => {
        // Display error message
        console.error('Error:', error);
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
    });
});

Explanation of the Code

  1. Email Validation:

    • The emailPattern regex checks if the email is in a valid format (e.g., example@domain.com).

    • If the email is invalid, an error message is displayed, and the form submission is stopped.

  2. Message Validation:

    • The messageWords array splits the message into words using spaces as delimiters.

    • If the message contains fewer than 2 words, an error message is displayed, and the form submission is stopped.

  3. Error Messages:

    • Error messages are displayed in the form-message div with red text.

    • Success messages are displayed with green text.

3. Add Styling for Error Messages (Optional)

You can add some CSS to style the error messages and make them more user-friendly.

css

    margin-top: 10px;
    font-size: 14px;
    font-weight: bold;
}

}

    • Leave the name or email fields empty and try to submit the form.

    • Enter an invalid email address (e.g., invalid-email) and try to submit the form.

    • Enter a single word in the message field and try to submit the form.

    • Enter valid data and verify that the email is sent successfully.

Final Notes

  • The required attribute ensures the fields cannot be left empty.

  • The type="email" attribute enforces basic email validation.

  • JavaScript provides additional validation for the email format and message length.

i wanna include location but not mandatory

To include a location field in your form that is not mandatory, you can add an optional input field for the location. Here's how you can update your form and JavaScript code:

1. Update the HTML Form

Add a new input field for the location. Since it’s optional, you don’t need to include the required attribute.

Updated HTML:

html
Copy
<form id="contactForm">
    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="name">Your Name <span style="color: red;">*</span></label>
        <input type="text" id="name" name="name" placeholder="Enter your name" required>
    </div>
    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="contact-info">Email <span style="color: red;">*</span></label>
        <input type="email" id="contact-info" name="contact-info" placeholder="Enter your email" required>
    </div>
    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="location">Location</label>
        <input type="text" id="location" name="location" placeholder="Enter your location (optional)">
    </div>
    <div class="form-group">
        <label for="message">Message <span style="color: red;">*</span></label>
        <textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Enter your message" required></textarea>
    </div>
    <button type="submit">Send Message</button>
</form>
<div id="form-message"></div>
Run HTML

  • The location field is optional, so it doesn’t have the required attribute.

  • The red asterisk (*) is only added to mandatory fields.

2. Update the JavaScript Code

Update the script.js file to include the location data when sending the email. Since the location is optional, you can include it in the email only if the user provides it.

Updated script.js:

javascript
Copy
// Initialize EmailJS with your Public Key
emailjs.init('hfbWk-2-MUzwJKl4'); // Replace with your Public Key

// Add an event listener to the form
document.getElementById('contactForm').addEventListener('submit', function (e) {
    e.preventDefault(); // Prevent the default form submission

    // Get form data
    const name = document.getElementById('name').value;
    const contactInfo = document.getElementById('contact-info').value;
    const location = document.getElementById('location').value; // Optional field
    const message = document.getElementById('message').value;

    // Validate email format
    const emailPattern = /^[^\s@]+@[^\s@]+\.[^\s@]+$/;
    if (!emailPattern.test(contactInfo)) {
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Please enter a valid email address.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
        return; // Stop further execution
    }

    // Validate message length (more than one word)
    const messageWords = message.trim().split(/\s+/);
    if (messageWords.length < 2) {
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Please write more than one word for the message.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
        return; // Stop further execution
    }

    // Prepare the email data
    const emailData = {
        name: name,
        contact_info: contactInfo,
        message: message,
    };

    // Include location only if provided
    if (location.trim() !== '') {
        emailData.location = location;
    }

    // Send email using EmailJS
    emailjs.send('service_vqll2la', 'template_e8rlxer', emailData)
    .then(() => {
        // Display success message
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Thank you! Your message has been sent.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'green';

        // Clear the form (optional)
        document.getElementById('contactForm').reset();
    }, (error) => {
        // Display error message
        console.error('Error:', error);
        document.getElementById('form-message').textContent = 'Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again.';
        document.getElementById('form-message').style.color = 'red';
    });
});

3. Update the EmailJS Template

If you want the location to appear in the email, update your EmailJS template to include the {{location}} variable.

Example EmailJS Template:

Copy
Subject: New Message from {{name}}

Name: {{name}}
Email: {{contact_info}}
Location: {{location}}
Message: {{message}}

  • If the user doesn’t provide a location, the {{location}} variable will be empty in the email.

4. Test the Form

  1. Open your website and fill out the form.

  2. Test the following scenarios:

    • Submit the form without entering a location.

    • Submit the form with a location.

    • Verify that the email includes the location (if provided) and that the form works as expected.

Final Notes

  • The location field is optional, so it doesn’t require validation.

  • The location data is included in the email only if the user provides it.

  • Update your EmailJS template to include the {{location}} variable if you want the location to appear in the email.
